G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the damages sought do not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Defendant conducts business in Norfolk County, and the incident that gave rise to this claim occurred within this jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6F.proposition: 2. Costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6F;

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6H.proposition: 3. Prejudgment and postjudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6H;

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) – Discussing a property owner’s duty to exercise reasonable care for invitees.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey is a leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care on possessors of land toward lawful visitors. Although the provided excerpt is a concurrence focused on trespassers, the majority opinion (referenced by the concurrence) expressly rejects the old invitee/licensee categories and defines the occupier’s duty in terms of reasonable care, thereby discussing and reshaping the duty owed to invitees. The concurrence assumes and “goes along with” that change in duty.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010) – Establishing liability for known hazards on property.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The case directly concerns premises liability for a slip-and-fall on ice in a parking lot and expressly holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a general duty of reasonable care with respect to hazards from snow and ice, just like other hazards. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and grounds liability in whether the owner knew or should have known of the hazardous condition and failed to act reasonably, which is consistent with the proposition of establishing liability for known hazards on property.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’… If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

Shepard v. Kelley, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 210.raw_text: Shepard v. Kelley, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 210 (2010)
Shepard v. Kelley, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 210.proposition: Shepard v. Kelley, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 210 (2010) – Duty to warn or remedy dangerous conditions.
Shepard v. Kelley, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 210.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns (1) Confrontation Clause issues with drug certificates and (2) whether a red rejection inspection sticker provides reasonable suspicion for a traffic stop. It does not address premises liability, landowner duties, or any duty to warn or remedy dangerous conditions. Thus, citing this case for a general duty to warn or remedy dangerous conditions is inaccurate and unsupported by the holding or reasoning.
Shepard v. Kelley, 77 Mass. App. Ct. 210.relevant_excerpt: "Here, by contrast, the presence of a certificate of rejection gave the officer reasonable grounds to believe that the car was being driven illegally. ... In sum, Detective Fraser had reasonable suspicion to stop the car. The motion judge properly denied the defendant’s motion to suppress."

Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Ligh.raw_text: Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Light Co., 333 Mass. 719 (1956)
Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Ligh.proposition: Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Light Co., 333 Mass. 719 (1956) – Proving foreseeability in negligence actions.
Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Ligh.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case about arson, murder, and admissibility/sufficiency of evidence, not a negligence action. The court does not analyze or articulate any general rule about foreseeability as an element of negligence; its brief reference to Commonwealth v. Welansky concerns the form of a murder indictment, not civil negligence standards. Therefore, citing this case for the proposition about proving foreseeability in negligence actions is inaccurate.
Correia v. New Bedford Gas & Edison Ligh.relevant_excerpt: Finally, Valcourt contends that the judge erred in denying his motions for directed verdicts of not guilty on the three murder indictments (assignment 31).... The indictments were drawn in accordance with the time honored method of charging the crime of murder, and they were in conformity with the form prescribed by G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 277, § 79. See Commonwealth v. Jordan, 207 Mass. 259, 266-267; Commonwealth v. Welansky, 316 Mass. 383, 395.

Berard v. Eaglebrook School, 81 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Berard v. Eaglebrook School, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 476 (2012)
Berard v. Eaglebrook School, 81 Mass. Ap.proposition: Berard v. Eaglebrook School, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 476 (2012) – Standard of reasonable care for invitees.
Berard v. Eaglebrook School, 81 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The reproduced opinion is not Berard v. Eaglebrook School but a Massachusetts Appeals Court decision involving Attorney Barry Wilson and a finding of summary criminal contempt. It concerns the scope and use of summary contempt power and standards for attorney courtroom conduct, not premises liability or the standard of reasonable care owed to invitees. Therefore, this opinion does not support the proposition about the reasonable care standard for invitees.
Berard v. Eaglebrook School, 81 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts, summary criminal contempt is governed by rule 43 (‘Summary Contempt Proceedings’). The rule states that ‘criminal contempt may be punished summarily when it is determined that such summary punishment is necessary to maintain order in the courtroom.’ … ‘[I]n reviewing the defendant’s claim that the judgment of summary contempt should be reversed on the ground that it is not supportable as matter of law … we will sustain the judge’s contempt finding if … the trial judge reasonably could have found that the [defendant’s] conduct was wilfully contumacious beyond a reasonable doubt.’”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: G.L. c. 231, § 85 – Comparative negligence principles in Massachusetts.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2013) – Business owner’s duty to maintain safe premises.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The case directly addresses and clarifies a landowner’s (including a landlord’s) duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition, even when the danger is open and obvious. The SJC holds that a possessor of land has a duty to remedy an unreasonably unsafe condition it created and maintained where it can and should anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter that condition despite the obvious risk. That is a core statement of a business/landowner’s duty to maintain safe premises, albeit in a residential rental context rather than a commercial business setting.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … [A] landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973) – Importance of notice in negligence cases.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the role of the defendant’s knowledge—actual or constructive—of a dangerous condition as an essential part of proving negligence in a premises liability slip-and-fall case. The court explains that a plaintiff must show the defendant created the condition, had actual notice, or that the condition existed long enough that the defendant should have discovered it, and ultimately reverses because the evidence did not adequately establish this notice/time element. This squarely supports a proposition about the importance of notice in negligence cases involving foreign substances on premises.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).proposition: Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977) – Presumption of negligence when hazardous conditions exist.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).support_reasoning: The case does not create any presumption of negligence from hazardous conditions. Instead, it holds that a landlord owes lawful visitors (including tenants’ guests) a duty of reasonable care in maintaining common areas, and that violation of a safety statute is admissible as *evidence* of negligence, not as a presumption or automatic finding of negligence. The opinion is explicit that statutory violations are merely evidence for the jury to consider, preserving the ordinary negligence framework rather than shifting burdens via a presumption.
Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79 (1977).relevant_excerpt: “In addition, G. L. c. 144, § 61… A jury could find that the absent light bulb showed that Massios violated this statute. Such a violation, if found, constitutes evidence of negligence… We hold today that the landlord’s duty of reasonable care to all visitors lawfully on premises within his control extends to his tenants’ visitors. Therefore, violation of a safety statute constitutes evidence of negligence in any action by a person whose only relationship to the premises where the injury occurred is that of a lawful visitor.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85A.proposition: G.L. c. 231, § 85A – Presumption of control and responsibility for business owners.
